abstracts.cdata!:
The environmental and social issues
            raised by the Sana'a Basin water management Program
            Project for the republic of Yemen are grouped as follows:
            design issues, including siting; construction issues,
            especially for dams; operational issues; dam safety issues;
            sustainability issues, especially water quality; pesticide
            issues; health issues; wastewater treatment plant issues;
            and resettlement issues. The objective of rehabilitating
            existing dams is itself a mitigation measure to address
            safety hazards. A dam safety expert has visited all sites
            and preliminarily concluded that the sites and foreseen work
            would not pose any safety risk. However, an international
            expert will also be retained to review feasibility studies,
            final designs, and bidding documents, and to participate in
            the Mid-Term Review. Recommended non-structural safety
            measures include installing instrumentation and monitoring
            devices, operation and maintenance plans, including
            emergency preparedness plans, and establishing a panel of
            three national experts, who would supervise final designs
            and safety measures. During construction, work areas
            susceptible to erosion will not remain exposed for long
            periods and sites will be restored to their original
            contours and revegetated where directed; shoring will be
            provided if needed in deeper trenches to ensure worker
            safety; reduce noise by scheduling work during the daytime;
            water worksites, quarries, and access roads to suppress
            dust; provide controls to concrete and batching plants to
            reduce air pollution and pollution of surface and
            groundwater; distance fueling from watercourses or recharge
            areas; put controls in place to prevent spillage; and have
            contractors clean up any accidental spills; employ strict
            measures for transport, storage, and use of explosives.
            Where there are archeological finds, cease construction
            until appropriate procedures for removal or preservation are
            issued; transplant any rare or endangered species to safe
            locations; to ensure worker health and safety, provide them
            safe drinking water and sanitation facilities, suitable
            clothing, first aid posts, and training in safe work
            practices. While the consumption of qat, the predominant
            crop in the Sana'a Basin, raises serious political,
            social, and public health issues, and its reduction is
            beyond the scope of this project, its consumption could be
            made less risky with measures to minimize pesticide
            residues. This report recommends demonstrating a model
            integrated pest management plan, regular testing for
            pesticide residues and farmer education, and monitoring of
            groundwater quality. There is some danger that the project
            works will increase the prevalence of schistosomiasis (or
            bilharzias). In that case, water bodies close to human
            habitations will be regularly inspected and monitored
            monthly to detect and identify the breeding of vectors and
            contain any colonies found through controlled spraying of
            insecticides and molluscicides. A specialist will oversee
            heath education and control measures. As for wastewater
            treatment plant issues, the accumulated dried sludge will be
            removed to a landfill site; a "red flag" system
            will warn farmers when raw sewage is being bypassed; a
            farmers will be educated on the hazards of treated and
            untreated wastewater; and a ban placed on the use of
            effluent to irrigate vegetables eaten raw.
